title: Go big or go niche: private equity at a crossroads
text:
One invitation to start: Join us for our first Due Diligence: Dialogues event next week as DD's James Fontanella-Khan and special guest Gregg Lemkau discuss the Goldman Sachs veteran's move from the sellside to the buyside and more. DD subscribers can register for free here.

As more private equity firms go public, smaller players face a big decision

2021 was a good year to be a listed private equity group.

A selection of 11 publicly traded players including US behemoths Blackstone and Apollo and Europe's EQT and Bridgepoint collectively gained almost $240bn in market value.

So it's little surprise that a growing number of firms are following suit, or at least thinking about it.

TPG is planning to float this month. CVC Capital Partners, Ardian and L Catterton have all had conversations with advisers about potential initial public offerings.

Several of the biggest players had a rocky start to life on the public markets, often trading below their IPO price in their early years. But they are surging now — and have used their time as listed entities to become sprawling, diversified asset managers.

That leaves smaller unlisted rivals at a crossroads: to stand a chance at keeping up, they'll need to bring in outside capital somehow. Or they must accept their fate as smaller, more specialised players.  

“The market is consolidating and the larger platforms are getting larger,” Michael Arougheti, chief executive of Ares Management, told DD's Antoine Gara and Kaye Wiggins. “A lot of smaller managers are feeling disadvantaged.”

Hellman & Friedman, Clayton, Dubilier & Rice and Advent International seem to be sticking to their roots as privately held shops that focus mostly on leveraged buyouts. So far, so is Thoma Bravo, whose co-founder Orlando Bravo told us that “to pursue our strategic mission, we don't need outside capital right now” — before adding that this could change.

The pitch to stock market investors is relatively simple: they're buying into a future stream of management fee income, which grows as the buyout group raises more, and larger, funds to deploy. Shareholders seem to like the relative predictability this provides.

Luckily for private equity dealmakers, that means they can keep to themselves the lion's share of performance fees — often the most lucrative stream of revenue. TPG has seized on this, restructuring its finances to give shareholders a greater claim to net management fees and dealmakers a greater claim to performance fees.

Another reason for European firms to think about listing now: unlike in the US, European regulators don't seem to be demanding full transparency about how much money top executives are making.

While Paris-listed Eurazeo does disclose carried interest payouts (chief executive Virginie Morgon pocketed €12.7m in 2016 on top of a €3.1m salary), EQT, Antin Infrastructure and Bridgepoint keep the figures under wraps.

That would be unthinkable in the US, where full disclosure of how much money bosses take home is seen as fundamental to the capitalist system.

Not in Europe, though. “It's an industry, particularly in the UK, which is obsessed with secrecy,” said Alain Rauscher, chief executive of Antin. “People don't want to communicate about their carried interest . . . You have some tabloid press who are going to make a big fuss about it.”

Credit Suisse squares off against SoftBank

SoftBank's Masayoshi Son has denied “all knowledge” of a controversial deal involving Greensill Capital. But Lex Greensill said in an email that Masa was “personally sighted on the issue”.

That's according to US legal filings from Credit Suisse.

The Swiss lender, which has been scrambling to recoup losses for its angry clients following Greensill's well-documented implosion, has pointed to what it calls a “material discrepancy” between the two. It launched legal action against SoftBank last month.

The dispute centres on $440m in funds that the bank's wealthy customers are owed by Katerra, a now-bankrupt US construction group and Greensill client that was backed by SoftBank's Vision Fund.

In late 2020, SoftBank agreed to give Greensill — which had lent Katerra money originally supplied by Credit Suisse clients — an emergency cash injection. (Katerra was included in Credit Suisse's Greensill supply-chain finance funds, which bundled invoices into investments and marketed them as low-risk.)

But as the FT revealed last year, Credit Suisse never received the money.

In its filings, the Swiss bank says Son denied “all knowledge of the Katerra” deal during a meeting with its chief Thomas Gottstein last September. But, it adds, an email sent by the Australian financier Lex Greensill in December 2019 said Masa was “personally sighted on the issue.”

The bank also claims that Lex Greensill gave a presentation to Son in October 2020 in which he discussed the Katerra restructuring.

“In light of these facts, Mr Son's stance in his meeting with Mr Gottstein is surprising and requires explanation,” according to a letter from the Swiss bank to SoftBank cited in the filings.

SoftBank seems unfazed. “Credit Suisse has been threatening to commence legal proceedings against SoftBank for the past six months, but has not done so — for the simple reason it has no evidence to support its fanciful claims,” the Japanese group said in a statement to the FT.

The saga has frozen relations between the two companies. SoftBank was once a key client of Credit Suisse, and Son himself was a longtime client of the bank.

The Japanese tech investor is “in the middle of a blizzard”, Son declared in November. The temperature has just plummeted even further.

Help wanted: London law firms squeezed by staff shortages

The magic circle seems to have lost its, er, magic touch.

London-based law firms are struggling to fill job vacancies, the FT's Kate Beioley reports, as soaring demand for legal services and an exodus from the industry sends headcounts plunging.

It's no secret that dealmakers have been weighing their golden handcuffs for some time, particularly at elite law firms where record M&A activity has left lawyers working gruelling hours and facing towering workloads.

In some cases, the deals frenzy has caused lawyers to experience debilitating burnout and other mental health issues. A survey of more than 1,700 lawyers published in September by LawCare, a mental health charity, found that nearly 70 per cent of respondents experienced ill health in 2021 including depression and anxiety.

Even sky-high retention bonuses (Kirkland & Ellis offered associates up to $250,000 to join the firm or stick around) and supercharged pay rises haven't slowed attrition rates, as firms struggle to fill the void.

Associates have now found themselves armed with unprecedented bargaining power. In some cases, lawyers can “name their price” not to walk out the door, said Daniel Harris, associate director at recruiter Robert Walters.

As the cost of talent keeps rising, DD wonders whether even the City's most prestigious firms will be able to foot the bill.

Job moves

PJT Partners has hired Hugo Baring as a partner, according to people familiar with the matter. He is currently head of TMT investment banking for Europe, the Middle East and Africa at JPMorgan Chase. PJT also hired John Allan, former chief executive of logistics company Exel, as a senior adviser based in London, according to an internal memo.

KKR has appointed Ryan Stork as chief operating officer. He joins from BlackRock where he was deputy chief operating officer. The private equity firm also appointed former Benchmark general partner Matthew Cohler to its board of directors.

Jefferies has appointed Philip Yates as vice-chair of its UK investment banking unit.

TPG has appointed Matt Jones as co-managing partner of TPG GP Solutions, the firm's US and European secondaries business, based in London.

Teneo managing director Matt Denham has joined PR agency Headland as a partner. Headland also promoted four directors to partners.

US football star Eli Manning has joined private equity firm Brand Velocity Partners as a partner.

Houlihan Lokey has hired Rouzbeh Fazlinejad as a managing director of its oil and gas team in Dubai, marking the investment bank's industry group in the Middle East. He was previously head of M&A at Berenberg.

Axel Springer, the German publisher that recently acquired Politico for about $1bn, has hired Goli Sheikholeslami, New York Public Radio's president and chief executive, as Politico Media Group's new chief executive. She starts in February.
